original_data.question: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe dyspnea and a productive cough containing streaks of blood since the day before. He had a sudden pruritic papular rash on his right thigh when he was in the southwestern USA hiking in northern Arizona and New Mexico. The next day he developed severely painful inguinal swelling on the same side; however, he did not see a physician and controlled the pain with painkillers. There is no other history of serious illness. He does not take any other medications. He appears confused. The temperature is 39.5℃ (103.1℉), the pulse is 105/min, the respiration rate is 32/min, and the blood pressure is 95/45 mm Hg. Rales are heard in the lower lobe of the left lung on auscultation. The right inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged with a spongy consistency and an underlying hard core. The surrounding area is edematous without overlying erythema or cellulitis. A computerized tomography (CT) scan is shown in the picture. Which of the following best explains these findings?

model_response:
This is a case of severe legionellosis (Legionnaire's disease). The cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis are typical symptoms of Legionnaire's disease. The rash is a common feature of legionellosis. The inguinal lymphadenitis is also a common finding. The CT scan shows bilateral lung involvement with a patchy distribution. The organism is a gram-negative bacillus that grows on BCYE agar. It is a facultative intracellular pathogen that infects macrophages. It is found in natural hot springs and contaminates cooling towers, air conditioners, and shower heads, which are the sources of the aerosols that infect susceptible individuals. The disease is prevented by keeping the temperature of the water below 50℃. Patients are treated with azithromycin or a respiratory fluoroquinolone.

Lyme disease is characterized by a characteristic rash (erythema chronicum migrans) and joint involvement. Malaria is characterized by fever and chills. Plague is characterized by the Black Death. "Legionnaire's disease".

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Difficult or labored breathing.
A cough accompanied by expectorated secretions.
Yellow-colored streaks, patches, or spots on the intimal surface of arteries. Fatty streaks stain red with Sudan III or Sudan IV. [PMID:8181179]
The body fluid that circulates in the vascular system (BLOOD VESSELS). Whole blood includes PLASMA and BLOOD CELLS.
Occurring or done each day.
A small (less than 5-10 mm) elevation of skin that is non-suppurative.
The ordinal direction halfway between south and west.
A unit of area equal to 4046.87261 square meters. The unit is based on the USA survey foot of 1200/3937 meters.
The activity of walking for recreation, exercise, or training that is usually strenuous and on unpaved surfaces.
One of the four primary cardinal directions. It is at 0 degree on a compass card. It is the direction to the left of sunrise.
State bounded on the north by Colorado, on the east by Oklahoma and Texas, on the south by Texas and Mexico, and on the west by Arizona.
Occurring or done each day.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
A line segment forming part of the perimeter of a plane figure.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
The act of directing or determining; regulation or maintenance of a function or action; a relation of constraint of one entity (thing or person or group) by another.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Compounds capable of relieving pain without the loss of CONSCIOUSNESS.
Record and study of past events.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
The act of ascertaining or fixing the value or worth of something.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Abnormal breath sounds (crackles) heard on auscultation, indicating inflammation, fluid, or infection of the lung.
A condition in which a person partially loses the ability to hear sounds in one or both ears.
The bottom most subdivision of either the right or left lung.
The 2-lobed lung located on the left side of the body.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
The lower right zone of the abdomen containing parts of the small intestine, appendix, cecum, ascending colon, and the right ovary and fallopian tube in females.
They are oval or bean shaped bodies (1 - 30 mm in diameter) located along the lymphatic system.

A type of osseous tissue which makes up the inner part of bone. It has a spongy, honeycomb-like structure with struts or trabecula and contains the BONE MARROW. It has higher rate of BONE REMODELING turnover than CORTICAL BONE.
A description about the firmness, uniformity or make-up of an entity.

The continents and countries situated on those continents; the UNITED STATES and each of the constituent states arranged by region; CANADA and each of its provinces; AUSTRALIA and each of its states; the major bodies of water and major islands on both hemispheres; and selected major cities.

An acute, diffuse, and suppurative inflammation of loose connective tissue, particularly the deep subcutaneous tissues, and sometimes muscle, which is most commonly seen as a result of infection of a wound, ulcer, or other skin lesions.
Tomography using x-ray transmission and a computer algorithm to reconstruct the image.
An image recorded by a camera.
